title: ColdBox: Easy

blocks.text: Initial Access
We start by scanning the target with Nmap.
As we can see, we found two ports: `http` and `ssh`. Since `ssh` requires credentials, we will leave it for now and focus on `http`.
Further Enumeration
Then I started to dive deeper by exploring the website and performing directory searching.
There, I saw many directories, but only one was worth checking: `secret`. So I decided to take a look at it, and we also noticed that it is a WordPress site.
At this stage, we saw three usernames. Now we just need a password.
WordPress Scan
As we already know it is a WordPress website, we will begin by exploring it with WPScan.

Here, we can see multiple users: `hugo`, `c0ldd`, `philip`, and `the cold in person`. We will start with the most prominent ones, `hugo` and `c0ldd`, because we saw these usernames when we visited the website.
Password Bruteforcing with Hydra
First, we will start with `hugo`.
After waiting for a couple of hours and getting nothing, I decided to switch to the next user, which is `c0ldd`.
With `c0ldd`, I found the password. Now we will use it to log in.
Post-Login Enumeration

We will start by exploring the WordPress website after logging in. While exploring, I realized we need to get a shell by uploading a malicious payload. I used a reverse shell generator to generate a payload. You can use a one-liner reverse shell or a Pentest Monkey shell scriptâ€”itâ€™s up to you. I needed to be quick, so I used a one-liner reverse shell.
You need to add your `Local IP` and `PORT`. You can generate this command by going to this URL: https://www.revshells.com/
Here is the UI you will see after logging in.
I clicked the `Editor` tab, and there I saw many pages. We can choose any page to inject our payload. I chose `content-none.php`, but you can use any page you like.

We encountered an issue: the script generated was for Bash, but we needed a PHP script. So I asked ChatGPT, and it gave me a PHP one-liner. You should understand the difference between different types of scripts.
Before doing anything, you need to open your terminal and run the following command. This will open a listener.
With the listener set up, all you have to do is trigger that PHP file. In my case, I used the search PHP file, so all I had to do was type anything in the search bar, and it triggered that PHP file.
Breaking into the System
With that, I got a shell, but it was `www-data`, so I had to escalate privileges.
I ran `ls` in that path and saw a `wp-config.php` file. I obtained the username and password from it, then used SSH with that user and gained a proper user shell.
User Flag
Then I simply ran `ls` and got the user flag by printing the `user.txt` file.
Privilege Escalation
Then I needed to gain a root shell, so I decided to type the most used command ever :)
Bingo! There, I saw that I could obtain a root shell in three ways. That means my user can run those three commands as root. I decided to try one of them and used `vim`.
Gaining Root Access with GTFOBins
I went to GTFOBins and searched for `vim`, where I found the command.
I needed a root shell, and that command was incomplete, so all I had to do was append `:!bash`.
When I executed this command, I got a `root` shell, and then I simply printed the flag.

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: Pyrat

blocks.text: Initial Access
We start by scanning the target with Nmap.
As we can see, we found two ports: `http` and `ssh`. Since `ssh` requires credentials, we will leave it for now and focus on `http`.
Further Enumeration
Then we visited website on the following url.
We can see it says, try a more basic conection so we will go with it and try to access it with a basic connection.
As we can see we got something like shell but it can only execute python code so now in next step we will setup a reverse shell.
Reverse Shell
Now we will setup reverse shell, so first we need python reverse shell so for this we will go to https://www.revshells.com
Remember to use your IP and PORT instead of the placeholders in the above command and before executing this open a listener in another tab by writing below command.
So as we can see we gained intital foothold and now we will check files and look for something which can give us any user access.
After enumerating we got a config file and upon viewing it we got username and password.
SSH
Now we will access into system via SSH and the credientials we got.
User Flag
With this we access user flag.
Root Flag
Ok so for root flag we will start by checking out files first
So here upon viewing gitconfig file we see it is referring to another directory which is /opt, so we will go there and check it.
So we restored a file and lets try to understand it.

So basically it is checking that if socket is admin or not so we know that we need to access it from admin and then we will write shell which will give us root shell, now will use a script which will bruteforce the password.
Now what we will do is to run this file, you can get this code from this url: https://github.com/Azid-ops/Important-Material---THM/blob/main/shell.py
So now we got the password and now remember admin is not any user but it is used in simple authentication so we just use that.

With data we logged in with normal admin user, which was supported in basic authentication and we wrote shell we got this information from the file we got before and in last we got the flag, thats it.

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: Anonforce

blocks.text: Initial Access
We start by scanning the target with Nmap.
As we can see, we found two ports: `ftp` and `ssh`. Since `ssh` requires credentials, we will leave it for now and focus on `ftp`.
From the image we can see that notread and tmp are NSE writeable, keep that in mind.
Writeable means we are able to write to those files
Further Enumeration
Then we will go to ftp and try to explore..
From nmap result we got our first flag by downloading and viewing user.txt
Privilege Escalation
After looking for some time i didn't get anyting intresting then i decided t go to notread directory which we got from nmap result
For detail understanding of pgp or gpg kindly go to gpg notes or gpg notes.
Now we need to decrypt these 2 files which we got, we would decrypt them with below commands.
First we know that private.asc contains private key which we need to decrypt backup file, but that file is also password protected so we are just extracting it passphrase.
This will give us the passphrase and we can enter this passphrase while decrypting, system will ask for that passphrase when decrypting.

First we load private key from .asc file and we decypted using that private key and we got the user and it's ssh password, by decrypting that password we got root shell and from there we got the root password.

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: ERROR BASED SQLI - MYSQL

blocks.text: What is ERROR BASED SQLI injecton attack?
Error Based SQLI is a type of injection attack where we can get database content from errors, to test if a webApp is vulnerable or no we can run the following command.
`'` if you use this and if you get mysql syntax error then bingo there is ERROR BASED injection in the web app.
How to See the Database?
From its name it is quite obvious, we can see the content by triggering an error.
By running above command you will see the database name as expected

blocks.code: SQLSTATE[HY000]: General error: 1105 XPATH syntax error: '~sqli_one~'

blocks.text: Here we used updatexml function which will ofc give us the error and we concat the database name with ~ to be more visible, we use this function because it give us some content rather than just telling there is an error. So this function expects something like this updatexml(xml_target, xpath_expression, new_value) we used 1 and 1 in place of xml_target and new_value let's try to understand these paramteres.
xml_target: So basically this function expects first param to be an xml document so we just gave it 1 to generate an error.
xpath_expression: It is the basically the parameter which is ging to parse by the MYSQL.
new_value: So this is the thing which will happen after successful parsing so we wrote 1 because we don't need it, you can write any useless thing in first and last parameter.
Important Note: The first and last parameter can be anything which is a valid sql but not a valid xml because we want invalid xml so that it fails.
Enumerate Tables
We have the database name so we will try to get the table names, you cannot get table names from basic sql syntax you need the below command to make it work.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND updatexml(1,concat(0x7e,(SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema='sqli_one' LIMIT 0,1),0x7e),1)

blocks.text: So from above command you can see the table names of the database.
Reading Columns
We have the table name, now we will ready it's column names, use the below command for that.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND updatexml(1,concat(0x7e,(SELECT column_name FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_name='article' LIMIT 0,1),0x7e),1)

blocks.text: This is pretty straight forward this will give you the column name
Reading Rows
We have the column name, now we can read that column data, from here you have everything so you can use normal msql query.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND updatexml(1,concat(0x7e,(SELECT username FROM article LIMIT 0,1),0x7e),1)

blocks.text: This is also pretty straight forward this will give you the row data

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: ERROR BASED SQLI - POSTGRES

blocks.text: What is ERROR BASED SQLI injecton attack?
Error Based SQLI is a type of injection attack where we can get database content from errors, to test if a webApp is vulnerable or no we can run the following command.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=5' AND CAST((SELECT version()) AS int)-- -

blocks.text: If you use above command and if you get postgres syntax error then bingo there is ERROR BASED injection in the web app.
How to See the Database?
From its name it is quite obvious, we can see the content by triggering an error.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND CAST((SELECT current_database()) AS int)-- -

blocks.text: By running above command you will see the database name as expected
Enumerate Tables
We have the database name so we will try to get the table names, you cannot get table names from basic sql syntax you need the below command to make it work.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND CAST((SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables LIMIT 1) AS int)-- -

blocks.text: So from above command you can see the table names of the database.
Reading Columns
We have the table name, now we will ready it's column names, use the below command for that.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1' AND CAST((SELECT column_name FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_name='users' LIMIT 1) AS int)-- -

blocks.text: This is pretty straight forward this will give you the column name
Reading Rows
We have the column name, now we can read that column data, from here you have everything so you can use normal postgres query.

blocks.code: http://www.test.com?id=1 AND CAST((SELECT username FROM article LIMIT 0,1) AS int)-- -

blocks.text: This is also pretty straight forward this will give you the row data

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: PGP DECRYPTION

blocks.text: What is PGP?
PGP is use to decrypt and ecrypt a file

Encrytption: For encrypton developer generate a private and a public key, with public key it can encrypt any file and pass that key to others so that they can encrypt as well. A public key is like a padlock.
Decryption: For decryption we need the same private key which developer created and he might stored that is some ascii file, so this private key is a key for that padlock.
What is a ASCII file?
Well developer can hide an private key in an ascii file, and he could protect that ascii file as well, so in order to see pgp file we need to have private key which we can get from ascii.
Below are some commands to decrypt the pgp file
For a practical understanding of gpg or gpg kindly look at Anonforce walkthrough.

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€

title: SUID BINARY ENUMERATION

blocks.text: What is a SUID binary??
SUID (Set User ID) is a special permission bit that allows a file to run with the privileges of its owner, not the user executing it.
The above command would list all binaries where SUID bit is set.
For example if you have a user azid and if he has the access to execute it, then it will be run with the privileges of its owner not from the person privileges who is executing it.
Let's Break this command shall we?
This says go ad match files but but but only match the regular files, dnt match folders, symlinks and etc just match regular files.
This 2> says that redirects error to output in short this command suppress errors if there is any error.
This says find any files with permission 4000, 4000 is suid in number terms.
Now we will run this command as it will execute that import os as root because we are using suid binary file, it will only work if UID and EUID is same if they are not same it will drop privileges.
This will print UID and EUID if they are not same so ofc when you call suid file it will drop privileges, it will show something like this (33, 0).
Here we changed our UID to 0, btw 0 UID is of root, so now when it will check UID is 0 and EUID is 0 then it will give us a root shell.

goodbyeMessage: Good luck, and happy hacking ðŸš€
